user.text: My friend wants to put my name down for a house he's buying. What risks would I be taking?

agent.speaker: agent
agent.text: There are several risks you might be taking if your friend puts your name down for a house he's buying.  Firstly, if you are co-signing the mortgage, the risk is that you will owe the bank the principal amount of the mortgage if your friend is unable to pay. You could come out of it a lot poorer and with your credit rating wrecked. Secondly, if you are not on the deed of the house, you would not have any legal rights to the property. This means that your friend could sell the house without your consent and you would still be responsible for the mortgage.  Thirdly, if your friend's house is a second home, he may not qualify for mortgage assistance or relief, increasing the risk for you as a co-signer.    Lastly, anyone considering this approach to talk to a lawyer and be aware of the potential tax implications.

That's speculation, of course, but such corrections are common-place over the long-term. If you buy a house today with the expectation of improving it and flipping it in six months, you run a very real risk of not recovering your initial investment, let alone the time and materials invested. Heck, you might not be able to sell the house at all. And from the parent's point of view, there's nothing to be done. agent.original_text:
Based on the documents provided, there are several risks you might be taking if your friend puts your name down for a house he's buying. 
Firstly, if you are co-signing the mortgage, you would be responsible for paying back the loan if your friend is unable to do so. This could lead to large mortgage payments and potential damage to your credit rating. 
Secondly, if you are not on the deed of the house, you would not have any legal rights to the property. This means that your friend could sell the house without your consent and you would still be responsible for the mortgage. 
Thirdly, if your friend's house is a second home, he may not qualify for mortgage assistance or relief, increasing the risk for you as a co-signer. 
Fourthly, the documents suggest that there is a risk of a market correction in real-estate prices, which could result in you not recovering your initial investment if you plan to improve and flip the house. 
Lastly, the documents advise that anyone considering this approach should consult a lawyer and be aware of the potential tax implications. 
It's important to note that these are general risks and the specifics may vary depending on your situation. Therefore, it's recommended that you consult with a legal professional before making any decisions.
